levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Performs the four operations with positive integers and simple fractions, following BIDMAS, but is still building confidence with negative numbers and mixed numbers.
common_errors: Adding numerators and denominators separately (getting 5/7)
Not converting to a common denominator

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applies operations fluently to integers (including negative), fractions, decimals and mixed numbers with accurate use of BIDMAS.
common_errors: Computing -3² as (-3)² = 9
Not applying BIDMAS to evaluate the power before the multiplication

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Operates fluently with all rational numbers, converting between representations and choosing efficient methods for each calculation.
common_errors: Squaring 2 and 1/3 separately to get 4 1/9
Not converting mixed numbers to improper fractions before operating

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies operations to irrational numbers and surds, and reasons about the structure of the number system (rational vs irrational closure properties).
levels.example_task: Show that the sum of a rational number and an irrational number is always irrational.
levels.example_response: Suppose r is rational and s is irrational, and r + s = q where q is rational. Then s = q - r. Since the rationals are closed under subtraction, q - r is rational. But s is irrational — contradiction. Therefore r + s must be irrational.
common_errors: Providing examples instead of a general proof
Not using the closure property of rationals under subtraction

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can express small numbers as products of prime factors using factor trees, and knows that 1 is not prime.
levels.example_task: Write 72 as a product of prime factors.
common_errors: Stopping before all factors are prime
Not using index notation

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses prime factorisation to find HCF and LCM of two or more numbers and applies these in problems.
levels.example_task: Find the HCF and LCM of 84 and 120.
common_errors: Taking the highest power for HCF instead of the lowest
Forgetting primes that only appear in one factorisation when computing LCM

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies prime factorisation to solve problems about divisibility, perfect squares and simplifying algebraic expressions.
levels.example_task: Find the smallest positive integer k such that 180k is a perfect cube.
levels.example_response: 180 = 2² × 3² × 5. For a perfect cube, all exponents must be multiples of 3. Need: 2³ (one more 2), 3³ (one more 3), 5³ (two more 5s). k = 2 × 3 × 25 = 150. 180 × 150 = 27,000 = 30³.
common_errors: Making all exponents even (perfect square) instead of multiples of 3 (perfect cube)
Not multiplying the required extra factors correctly

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Uses the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic in proofs and understands its uniqueness — every integer > 1 has exactly one prime factorisation.
levels.example_task: If the HCF of two numbers is 12 and their LCM is 360, and one number is 72, find the other number.
levels.example_response: HCF × LCM = product of the two numbers. 12 × 360 = 72 × n. n = 4320/72 = 60. Verify: 72 = 2³ × 3², 60 = 2² × 3 × 5. HCF = 2² × 3 = 12 ✓. LCM = 2³ × 3² × 5 = 360 ✓.
common_errors: Not knowing the HCF × LCM = product property
Not verifying the answer

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Evaluates integer powers and finds square and cube roots of perfect squares and cubes.
common_errors: Computing 2⁵ as 10 (multiplying base by exponent)
Not knowing that cube roots of negative numbers are negative

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applies the laws of indices (multiplication, division, power of a power) and works with zero and negative integer exponents.
common_errors: Adding exponents when dividing
Multiplying exponents when adding powers with the same base

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Works with standard form and applies index laws to expressions involving fractional indices and surds.
common_errors: Not converting 8 to 2³ to unify the base
Computing 8^(2/3) as 8 × 2/3

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Simplifies and manipulates surd expressions, rationalises denominators, and proves results about irrational numbers. (Higher tier)
common_errors: Not multiplying by the conjugate
Errors in the difference of two squares computation in the denominator

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can round numbers to a given number of decimal places and uses estimation to check answers.
levels.example_response: 3.4567 ≈ 3.46 (the third decimal digit is 6 ≥ 5, so round up).
common_errors: Rounding to 2 significant figures instead of 2 decimal places
Not looking at the correct digit to decide rounding direction

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Rounds to significant figures, uses estimation to check calculations, and understands the difference between truncation and rounding.
levels.example_task: Estimate (4.89 × 0.0312) / 0.52 by rounding to 1 significant figure.
levels.example_response: ≈ (5 × 0.03) / 0.5 = 0.15 / 0.5 = 0.3. (Exact answer: 0.2930... so the estimate is reasonable.)
common_errors: Not rounding 0.0312 to 0.03 (treating it as 0)
Rounding too aggressively, losing all useful information

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Calculates error intervals for rounded and truncated values using inequality notation, and applies appropriate accuracy in context.
levels.example_task: A length is 4.7 cm to 1 decimal place. Write the error interval.
common_errors: Writing 4.65 < L < 4.75 (the lower bound should be inclusive)
Computing bounds as 4.7 ± 0.1 instead of ± 0.05

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Propagates errors through calculations, determines appropriate precision for final answers, and understands the limits of measurement accuracy.
levels.example_task: p = 3.4 (1 d.p.) and q = 1.2 (1 d.p.). Find the error interval for p/q.
levels.example_response: p: 3.35 ≤ p < 3.45. q: 1.15 ≤ q < 1.25. Min p/q: 3.35/1.25 = 2.68. Max p/q: 3.45/1.15 = 3.00. Error interval: 2.68 ≤ p/q < 3.00. To minimise a quotient, use smallest numerator and largest denominator; to maximise, use largest numerator and smallest denominator.
common_errors: Using smallest q for minimum (should use largest q for minimum quotient)
Not understanding that division flips the direction of the bounds
